title: Designing a wine lable, no idea what to use
content:
Although typeface intrigues me, I’ll admit, I do not have an eye for it. My strength lies mostly in illustration. I’m working on a wine label for a computer graphics class and I can’t figure out what to use for the name.

Feel free to critique the heck out of the design itself while your at it, I’m more than open to it.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103042014im_/http:/typophile.com/files/wine%20lable_3992.gif)
author: Greenstarcandy

comments.content:
Hello.  
Helsinki has a cold weather, right? Could you describe the characteristics of the product? It helps to know that...

I recommend a site where you can watch and analize more wine bottles and the font used on the pack:

[http://lovelypackage.com/category/alcohol/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103042014/http:/lovelypackage.com/category/alcohol/ "http://lovelypackage.com/category/alcohol/")

///Gerardo Ruiz Babsia///

Try Museo, it’s pretty awesome and should compliment the Illo style – and two of the weights are free.

[http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/exljbris/museo/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103042014/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/exljbris/museo/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/exljbris/museo/")

Shopping locally might be a good approach. Sami Kortemäki lives in Helsinki and is a founding member of Underware. [Liza](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103042014/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/underware/liza/) or [Dolly](http://web.archive.org/web/20100103042014/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/underware/dolly/) could work beautifully on a wine bottle.

There’s an i missing from the top “Helsinki Finland”.

As a Helsinki born Finn I don’t get my home town feeling in the lable. The official city of Helsinki these days is all Helvetica, but there’s also plenty of Jugend/Art Nouveu in the old buildings.
